content.description: Climb thin vertical crack that widens as it intersects a fat horizontal crack at the level of the roof to left.  Pass the tree and work the off-width for a couple of moves to the top.
content.protection: Standard rack. A 6" cam protects to top moves. Walk off. Trees on top suitable for TR anchors
content.location: Toward the left end of cliff, look for a tree growing out of a crack 25 ft. up.

content.description: Climb the vertical crack just to the left of the lichen patch.  It starts thin and turns into a small right-facing corner that leads to a small ledge/alcove with a tree and boulder.
content.protection: Standard rack. Walk off. Trees on top suitable for TR anchors.
content.location: Crack left of large lichen patch.

content.description: Climb a short left-facing corner to a small, triangular roof.  Exit the roof at the left and follow the vertical crack straight up to the top.
content.protection: Standard rack. Walk off. Trees on top suitable for TR anchors.

content.description: Climb the broken cracky area.  The easiest route in the Lower Ledges.
content.protection: Standard rack. Walk off. Trees on top suitable for TR anchors.
content.location: About a third of the way from the right side of the crag.  A broken, cracky section of rock leading to a tree.

content.description: Climb the slab on the right side of the lichen patch to a thin seam that comes from the left then turns straight up.  Follow the seam to the top.
content.protection: Trees at top suitable for TR anchors.
content.location: Middle of the ledge, just right of the large lichen patch.

content.description: Climb the face to a stance in a rectangular depression about halfway up.  Then continue up to top.
content.protection: Trees at top suitable for TR anchors.
content.location: Equidistant between large lichen patch and left-facing corner with roof.  Just let of large tree at cliff's edge.

content.description:
Possible first ascent? I was not able to find a description for this route in any guide book or website. Please update/change the name if incorrect.

 Before attempting be aware that this route needs cleaning! The horizontal crack is very thin and dirty.

 Use the same start as First Timer, begin traversing left using the horizontal for feet and the ramp on top of the triangular block for hands. Where the triangular block ends downclimb slightly using friction moves to find thin feet on the slab (area is a tiny bit mossy). Continue traversing left and slightly down again on the slab to good feet while using the thin horizontal crack for hands/fingers. You will intersect Try or Fly at the small triangular roof then exit up the vertical crack as you would when finishing Try or Fly.
content.protection: DB #3 camalot to micros, small tricams were also handy
content.location: Start is the same as First Timer at the 3 foot roof which turns into left-facing corner.

content.description: Climb the face and seams above a small overhang 3 ft. off the ground to a short, 5" vertical crack at the top.
content.protection: Trees at top suitable for TR anchors.
content.location: 8 feet from rightmost end of crag.  Walk off.

content.description: Follow a thin, vertical crack that starts in a left-facing corner.  Halfway up the crack opens up to a 3 inch slot.  Continue straight up to the top.
content.protection: Standard rack.  Walk off. Trees on top suitable for TR anchors.
content.location: About 12 feet left of the far right end, where the 3 foot high overhang turns into a left-facing corner.

content.description: The Lower Ledges are smaller and shorter than the other ledges.  The climbs are more vertical and are about 20-30 ft. tall.
